Teacher holding a smartphone to test
Mark words not read correctly on last test
Unmark words not read correctly on last test

Press any word that the student does not read correctly to mark it red. Press the word again to unmark it if the student reads it correctly.

When done, press the check mark at the bottom of the screen to save the test result.

You can mark or unmark the words not read correctly on the student\'s last test by pressing the grid icon in the menu.
Girl with big smile in classroom
Add other student after this one.
Teacher planning based on test results from smartphone

You are going to delete all test results from %1$s %2$s.

Are you sure?
Another student in your class has this name
Graph will be shown with 2 or more test results
The maximum number of tests per student is %1$d.
You have reached the maximum number of tests per student (%1$d tests).
Press the plus button to add a new test for this student.

This app helps you test your students’ recognition of the two most commonly used Sight words lists: Dolch words and Fry words.


Default test.

All students in your class will be tested by default on one type of test but you can choose a different type of test for any particular student.
Students tested on the default test will be displayed in blue. Students tested on a test different that the default test will be shown in brown.


How to administer tests.

• Add students to your class.
• Download and print the word list of the test you are going to administer.
• Press the student you are going to test.
• Press the plus button to add a new test.
• Let the student read the words on the words list you printed, and press any word that the student does not read correctly. Once finished press the check mark button to save the test result.


How results are displayed.

The main screen of the app will display the number of words read correctly and the date of the last test administered to the students.
When you press on a particular student you will see all the tests administered to him.
When a student reads all words correctly on a test, this result will be displayed with a colored background.


App Widget.

This app has a Widget that displays all the information found on the main screen of the app.


How information is saved.

All the information you save on the app is stored on a database in your device and it is accessible only by this app.
All previous results for this student will be deleted if you change the students test.
Please select a CSV (comma-separated values) file with the following information on each line:
The maximum number of students in your class is %1$d.
You can create and edit a CSV (comma-separated values) file on most spreadsheets programs such as Microsoft Excel or Google Spreadsheets or in any plain text editor like the Windows Notepad.
Show message about CSV file format when pressing the load students option.

You are going to delete this test from %1$s %2$s:

%3$s
%4$s
%5$s words read correctly.

Are you sure?

A PDF file provides an electronic image of text and graphics that looks like a printed document and can be viewed, printed, and electronically transmitted. Multiple programs can use PDFs for example Adobe Acrobat Reader and Foxit Reader.

A CSV (comma-separated values) file allows data to be saved in a tabular format that can be used with most spreadsheets program, such as Microsoft Excel or Google Spreadsheets.

A simple file will contain the information you see on the screen.

A detailed file will contain the same information of a simple file plus words not read correctly.

First name option will sort students by first name then by last name.

Last name option will sort students by last name then by first name.

Test result option will sort students by test type then by test result then by last name and finally by first name.

Test type option will sort students by test type then by last name and finally by first name.

A words list can be printed or shown on a screen for the student to read its words while you use this app to mark the words he does not read correctly.

Flash cards can be used to let the student practice reading the words of a particular test.

The maximum number of oldest tests to delete is the number of tests from this student minus 1, in order to keep at least one test result after deletion.

\nThere is a student in your class with this name already.\n

%1$s %2$s.

%3$s
%4$s
%5$d words read correctly.

Words not read correctly:
%6$s.

Sight words are words that should be memorized to help a child learn to read and write. Learning sight words allows a child to recognize these words at a glance — on sight — without needing to break the words down into their individual letters and is the way strong readers recognize most words. Knowing common, or high frequency, words by sight makes reading easier and faster, because the reader does not need to stop to try and sound out each individual word, letter by letter.

The two most commonly used sight words lists are the Dolch words and the Fry words.

The Dolch Sight Words list is the most commonly used set of sight words. Educator Dr. Edward William Dolch developed the list in the 1930s-40s by studying the most frequently occurring words in children’s books of that era. The list contains 220 “service words” plus 95 high-frequency nouns. These words comprise 80% of the words you would find in a typical children’s book and 50% of the words found in writing for adults. Once a child knows this list of words, it makes reading much easier, because the child can then focus his or her attention on the remaining words.

The Dolch words are divided into groups by grade level, ranging from pre-kindergarten to third grade, with a separate list of nouns. There are a total of 315 Dolch Sight Words.

The Fry Sight Words list is a more modern list of words, and was extended to capture the most common 1,000 words in the English language. Dr. Edward Fry developed this expanded list in the 1950s (and updated it in 1980), based on the most common words to appear in reading materials used in Grades 3-9. Learning all 1,000 words in the Fry list would equip a child to read about 90% of the words in a typical book, newspaper, or website.

The Fry words are listed by the frequency with which they occur and are broken down into groups of 100. So the first 100 Fry words are the 100 most frequently occurring words in the English language.

Pre-K (40 words): a, and, away, big, blue, can, come, down, find, for, funny, go, help, here, I, in, is, it, jump, little, look, make, me, my, not, one, play, red, run, said, see, the, three, to, two, up, we, where, yellow, you.

Kindergarten (52 words): all, am, are, at, ate, be, black, brown, but, came, did, do, eat, four, get, good, have, he, into, like, must, new, no, now, on, our, out, please, pretty, ran, ride, saw, say, she, so, soon, that, there, they, this, too, under, want, was, well, went, what, white, who, will, with, yes.

First Grade (41 words): after, again, an, any, as, ask, by, could, every, fly, from, give, going, had, has, her, him, his, how, just, know, let, live, may, of, old, once, open, over, put, round, some, stop, take, thank, them, then, think, walk, were, when.

Second Grade (46 words): always, around, because, been, before, best, both, buy, call, cold, does, don’t, fast, first, five, found, gave, goes, green, its, made, many, off, or, pull, read, right, sing, sit, sleep, tell, their, these, those, upon, us, use, very, wash, which, why, wish, work, would, write, your.
